template_data.title: What is an EDGE species
template_data.window_text: This is a visualization of the tree of life: all species know to science should exist somewhere on this huge tree. To explain what an EDGE species is, we’ll start by finding something familiar that isn’t an EDGE species: ourselves!

template_data.title: Lots of our relatives are globally endangered
template_data.window_text: In this tree, we show species that are threatened with extinction as red leaves. If we zoom out you can see that a huge number of our close relatives are red: they are Globally Endangered.

template_data.title: Many parts of the tree contain globally endangered species
template_data.window_text: It’s not just our close relatives. Many other parts of the tree of life are full of globally endangered species, for example the turtles.

template_data.title: How should we prioritise conservation of endangered species?
template_data.window_text: With so many globally endangered species, and limited resources for conservation, which species should we be most worried about?

template_data.title: Some species are particularly distinct
template_data.window_text: Some species, like the duck billed platypus, have special features not seen elsewhere on the tree of life. What is it about species like the duck billed playtpus that makes them so special?

template_data.title: Distinctness comes from years of separate evolution
template_data.window_text: The playpus has no close living relatives, it’s all that’s left on the end of a branch that’s been evolving for 60 million years.

template_data.title: Evolutionary Distinct species have few close relatives
template_data.window_text: Even when we look at its nearest relatives, there aren’t many of them and that makes the playpus even more special. We say it is Evolutionary Distinct, but fortunately it is not Globally Endangered

template_data.title: EDGE species are both distinct and endangered
template_data.window_text: Some species are both Evolutionary Distinct (ED) and Globally Endangered (GE). These EDGE species are both special and at risk of extinction.

template_data.title: A classic example of a set of EDGE species
template_data.window_text: Another example is the Panglins, there are only 8 living species, most of which are endangered and all are threatened with extinction. They are all that's left of a branch of the tree of life that's been evolving for 65 million years.
